none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 31, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 31, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 20 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

Agricultural and Mechanical College
—:— OF TEXAS. —:—

CORRESPONDENCE
ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE
PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO
THE CHAIRMAN.
WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH
THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT, ON
ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO
AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE.
WE MAKE A SPECIALTY OF FINE
STOCK.

Department Agriculture and Horticulture
[Image: Star]
GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A.

FACULTY.
CHAIRMAN:
H. H. DINWIDDIE.
TREASURER:
L. L. McINNIS.
J. R. COLE. R. WIPPRECHT.
W. L. BRINGHURST,
GEO. W. CURTIS,
R. H. WHITLOCK,
R. F. SMITH.

Chicago Ills.
College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, July 13th 1885

My Dear Prof.:

Yours recd.
here - Wife brought it in with
her when she came in to
Chicago to wait for me —
Very many thanks for your
kindness - I want you to
write me at Anamosa Iowa
& give me the true inside
of some things — How did S-
secure an appointment by the
Board? Was glad to meet him
there but suspect there is
something back of it which I
do not know. Shall send
the Voucher rck & Exch. as soon
as we get to Anamosa & will
then ck. for amt. due College
from me as pr your request
Josie tells me — by letter that
the calves are doing well & W—
wrote to same effect. Wish I
could see you & talk over some
things — Will see what can
be done about the house &
servants & write you more
anon. — Had a splendid time
in Convention — Am one of the
executive Com. of C. for future work
Mrs C. joins with me in
Best of wishes to all especially
the Baby

Ever truly.
G W Curtis

**Transcription Process Deep Dive**

Okay, here's how I'm approaching this transcription, breaking down each thought step-by-step to be as accurate as possible for this expert user. I'm taking on the role of a professional transcriptionist, focusing on detail and adhering to the given guidelines.

First, I'm setting the stage: the task is to transcribe from this image, maintaining high accuracy, including original spelling and punctuation. The goal is a clean HTML output, so I'm paying special attention to how I can use tags like `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, `sup`, Markdown tables (though it seems the data is represented by a 3 column format) and clear structural labels like "Header". My only constraint: produce only the final transcript, no commentary.

Next, I'm analyzing the image's components. I'm seeing an official letter, likely on College stationery. The header looks important and includes the name "Agricultural and Mechanical College OF TEXAS," with faculty listed and departmental info. This header includes instructions for correspondence, a list of faculty, and a specific departmental header "Department Agriculture and Horticulture" with a star logo. This letter is dated "Chicago Ills. July 13th 1885". The text is handwritten in cursive, appearing rapidly written, and uses purple ink. The content of the letter seems to be personal and professional correspondence about travel, an appointment by the Board (mentioned with a letter "S-"), vouchers, Anamosa Iowa, and family. It is signed "G. W. Curtis" (matching the printed name on the letterhead).

Now, the methodical transcription begins.

*   **Header Section**: I'm focused on the layout. "Agricultural and Mechanical College OF TEXAS" (Old English font) is the main title. There's small text in a left column ("CORRESPONDENCE") and a right column ("FACULTY"). A center graphic shows "Department Agriculture and Horticulture," a star image, and "GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A.".

*   **Date/Location Line**: This is where it gets tricky because the printed "College Station, Brazos Co., Texas," is overwritten or has handwriting above and beside it. The actual location seems to be "Chicago Ills" (handwritten *above* the printed text). The date is handwritten: "July 13th 1885".

*   **Salutation**: "My Dear Prof.:" starts the letter.

*   **Body Paragraphs**: I'm carefully deciphering the cursive, letter-by-letter. Key phrases, which I'll be meticulously transcribing include: "Yours recd.", "Wife brought it in with," "Anamosa Iowa", and trying to decode the mysteries like "How did S- secure". The handwriting presents challenges, particularly around the "Voucher" and the name or abbreviation after "S-".

*   **The Voucher Challenge**: The most difficult part is transcribing "Voucher [?] & [?]". After much analysis, and comparing with the word "back" from the previous sentence, looking closely, I've tried "Voucher, ck & Exch.", "Voucher ret & Exch." or "Voucher rck & Exch." because it fits the context of financial or administrative tasks. I can't be certain. The '&' looks clear and the second word looks most like "Exch." (Exchange). or "Cole" but the ampersand rules that out. The "rck" could be "vck". So I'll transcribe "Voucher [?] & Exch.". I'll keep the "[?]" mark to be conservative with what I see on the page. I am going to try "Voucher rck & Exch." with my best guess. But I could also see "Voucher ret & Exch." (ret= returned)

*   **Additional Words**: "Josie tells me" looks clear. "W—" likely refers to someone, maybe Wipprecht, the faculty member from the header.

*   **Closing**: It is "Ever truly" followed by a signature "G W Curtis".

To structure the HTML output for the header, I'll use paragraph tags (`p`) for blocks of text. The faculty list will use some formatting, possibly linear text, because tables feel overkill. I'll maintain the original intent/layout as best I can using HTML formatting.

Next, I'm refining my interpretation of the handwriting. For the "Voucher" line, I'm re-evaluating: I'm focusing on the strokes and shapes. The word between "Voucher" and "&" is tricky. Could be "ret", it could be "rck". "ck". I'll

W
29 - winona
Friday 31 -
Sat 1 -
Thu 6
Friday 7
Mo 10 Way
Thus 13 -
Mon - 17 austin
k 24 [illegible]
25 College -

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Itinerary** Okay, here's what I've got. This looks like a handwritten itinerary or schedule, likely from a pencil document, and I'm going to get this right. First, I'm analyzing the image; it's a list of dates and locations or notes. The handwriting is cursive, a bit messy, but legible enough, though the pencil makes some parts faint. Here we go: 1. I see a "W" at the top of the list; it's probably short for a day of the week. 2. Next line: "29 - winona". The "29" is clear. "winona" looks like a lowercase, handwritten "w." 3. Line three: "Friday 31 -". "Friday" is standard. The date looks like "31", even though the '1' has a tail, the calendar implies it's the end of a month. Dash after 31. 4. Line four: "Sat 1 -". "Sat" and "1" are clear. There is a dash. 5. Line five: "Thu 6". The "Thu" looks like it could be "Thus", but the context makes it "Thu." The number "6" is clear. 6. Line six: "Friday 7". "Friday" and "7" are clear. 7. Line seven: "Mo 10 Way". "Mo" clearly stands for "Monday". "10" is obvious. "Way" looks like a plausible location. 8. Line eight: "Thus 13 -". I was debating "Thurs," but the handwriting looks like "Thus" with the tail, though the "s" is a little wonky. It's almost "Thms". But I will transcribe "Thus". Dash at the end. 9. Line nine: "Mon - 17 austin". "Mon" is standard. There is a dash between "Mon" and "17". "austin" is lowercase and clear. 10. Line ten: "k 24 [illegible]". The first character looks like a "k" or maybe a ditto mark. Following that, there is "24". There's then a diamond-shaped strike-through, and I can make out some letters inside, like "dush" or "Aust" - it looks like a crossed out word. Given the previous line, it's likely "austin," but I'm going to represent that as "[illegible]" because the handwriting is ambiguous in the strike-through, I must focus on the visuals. 11. Line eleven: "25 College -". "25" and "College" are clear. Dash at the end. Now, final thoughts, the date "31" makes sense from the context. "winona" and "austin" are lowercase, and "Way" and "College" are capitalized. It's just a simple transcription task. Ready! ```html

W
29 - winona
Friday 31 -
Sat 1 -
Thu 6
Friday 7
Mo 10 Way
Thus 13 -
Mon - 17 austin
k 24 [illegible]
25 College -
